div.p: In the experiment SC 4572, we explored the influence of the two osmolytes ectoine and hydroxyectoine on the structure of pure water and aqueous NaCl solutions using non-resonant X-ray Raman scattering spectroscopy at the oxygen K-edge. Both ectoine and hydroxyectoine are naturally occurring organic osmolytes synthesized by halophilic organisms that live in high-salt and other extreme environments. We find that X-ray spectroscopic data at the oxygen K-edge are consistent with a scenario where both osmolytes a ect the ff hydrogen bonding network of water on a local scale to in e ect increase tetrahedral order. This supports the ff proposed stabilizing mechanism of the osmolytes for proteins: preferential exclusion of the osmolytes from the proteins' surface and preferential hydration of the macromolecules instead of complex alterations to the structure of water on a bulk scale. The e ect of NaCl on water, a disruption of hydrogen bonds and tetrahedral ff order, acts in opposition to the localized water-binding e ects of ectoine and hydroxyectoine. For ternary ff mixtures of osmolyte in the presence of NaCl, the e ects seen in the spectra are found to be additive such that ff the mixed solutes generate a level of oppositional frustration in the water network.

The results have been published as: C.J. Sahle, M.A. Schroer, C.M.Jeffries, J. Niskanen. Hydration in aqueous solutions of ectoine and hydroxyectoine. Phys. Chem. Chem. Phys. 20, 27917 -27923 (2019). Doi: 10.1039/c8cp05308a
